bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 5, 1900

div1.p: Kean writes about his rationale for remaining as Post Surgeon at Columbia Barracks instead of taking position at Fort McHenry, Baltimore. He comments on the lasting value of Reed's work.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 5, 1900
div1.p:
I have arisen early
in the morning to have
my letter catch todays
mail, and try to make
my peace with you, for
I know that you will be
disappointed to hear that
we are not coming back
to the U. S. for yet a little
while, For I have been
given my choice and have
elected to be Post Surgeon
at Columbia Bks rather
than at McHenry- The
sacrifice in rank in pay
and in responsibilities in-
voled in accepting the
latter was too great altho,
the opportunities for Study
would be fine - and the
post is one of my choice.
The way of the matter was
this. The good General
when in Washington asked
that Mickie & I, the only
two of his old 7th Corps
staff left him, be sent
with him to Omaha- As
there was no regular S. G.
at Omaha it was readily
granted in Mickie's case
but a Col. had recently
been sent there as Chief
Surgeon so it was out of
the question for me- When
the General told me of this
application I thanked him
but said I did not care
to go to the U. S. if I had to
surrender my Vol. commission as Major,
as is the Custom in the Med Corps-
So the General at once cabled the S. G.
“Kean does not wish station in U. S. unless
he can retain Vol. commission”- About
this time in the day along came the family
cable of congratulation, which showed that
something was in the wind for me-
Later in the day the S. G. cabled me-
“I shall expect you to resign your Vol. com-
mission as Major two minutes after your
arrival at Fort McHenry. Do you prefer
to remain in Cuba”- To which after
seeing Havard the Chief Surgeon of Div. I
cabled that I preferred to remain in
Cuba as a Major- The difference
in pay including the 10% for tropical
service is $900-a year- Havard has
been very nice in wishing me to stay &
in offering me the best station in Cuba,
and Stark has been also very generous
in expressing his willingness to give up
Columbia Bks & go to Matanzas-

So I am settled now till spring - and
shall try to pay my debts instead of con-
tracting more of as I would have had to do
to move and outfit the family with winter
clothes-

Well my little family
came back to me look-
ing as fine as fiddles-
Louis has, I suppose
written you of her trip
down- Bobbie is a
fine lad, and his
profile is his Gran's
over again. He is a
Hurlbut all over and
you should have exer-
cised your right to
give him the Hurlbut
name- tho. his name
as well as the good little
rascal himself, give
me constant pleasure-
We are still camping
out in Gen. Lee's cot-
tage which he will now
not occupy- When we
will move out of there
into a house of our own
I dont know, but it will
be soon- The Dept will
break up the middle
of the month & I will then
go to Col. Bks- Gen
Wood & his Staff all
coming out to our Hdqrs.
as the fever is worse now
in Havana than it has been this
summer- But there is none at
all out here, and the only three
cases at Columbia Bks in since
August have been caused by
mosquito inoculations- So you
see as long as Louise dont offer
herself & the children to Reed
for experimental purposes they
are perfectly safe-

Reed will be back on Wednesday
His discovery is I believe of incalcu-
lable value to Cuba and the
United States, and will give him
enduring fame in his profession-
He can, and will both check the
breeding of mosquitoes in towns &
prevent their infection from yellow
fever cases, & thus prevent the
propagation of the disease-
